title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of a strong automotive industry for the economic health of the United States, with automotive sales historically contributing significantly to retail spending and providing financial security for many Americans. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of automotive sales fluctuated between approximately 14.2 million and 17.5 million units from June 2006 to May 2008. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of automotive sales has declined significantly since June 2008, averaging less than 10,000,000 units and only exceeding this number in three months. It has not reached the threshold of 13,000,000 units, indicating a weakened automotive industry. The automotive new vehicle dealers industry has substantial annual contributions to the national economy. In 2008, the average sales revenue for around 20,000 new automobile dealers in the United States was $28.8 million, with total sales reaching $576 billion, accounting for 14.6% of total retail sales in the country. In 2008, new-vehicle dealerships in the United States employed 1,057,500 people, with an average of 53 employees per dealership. The average annual salary was $48,963, generating a national payroll of over $52 billion. This also resulted in millions in tax revenue for State and local governments. The new-vehicle dealer industry in the United States has a national payroll of over $52 billion, with an average of $2.66 million per dealership. This industry is crucial for the success of automobile manufacturers, especially during economic challenges, and plays a significant role in generating tax revenue for State and local governments. A reduction in the cost of capital for financing new vehicles will benefit the new-vehicle dealer industry, automotive manufacturing, and the national economy. Nonmortgage interest payments, like automobile loan debt, were deductible for Federal income tax for 73 years. The deduction for nonmortgage interest payments, including automobile loan debt, was deductible for Federal income tax for 73 years until Congress ended it in 1986 with the Tax Reform Act. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a passenger car or light truck was eliminated in 1986 with the Tax Reform Act. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated the deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a passenger car or light truck. Additionally, an amendment was made to section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code to include a new subparagraph (G) related to qualified vehicle interest for vehicles acquired when the national unemployment rate is not less than 7 percent. An amendment to section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code introduced a new subparagraph (G) for qualified vehicle interest when the national unemployment rate is at least 7 percent. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated the deduction for interest on indebtedness for acquiring a passenger car or light truck. A new provision, qualified vehicle interest, allows for a deduction when the national unemployment rate is at least 7 percent. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated the deduction for interest on acquiring a passenger car or light truck. Qualified vehicle interest allows a deduction up to $5,000 for a qualified vehicle, with a 36-month period limitation on the interest deduction. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated the deduction for interest on acquiring a passenger car or light truck. Qualified vehicle interest allows a deduction up to $5,000 for a qualified vehicle, with a 36-month period limitation on the interest deduction. The term 'qualified vehicle' refers to a motor vehicle acquired for personal use by the taxpayer. The taxpayer can deduct interest on a qualified vehicle acquired for personal use, meeting specific criteria such as being acquired for use and not resale, not receiving payment under a specific act, being made by a manufacturer, and treated as a motor vehicle for title II purposes. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to any vehicle meeting specific criteria, including being made by a manufacturer, treated as a motor vehicle for Clean Air Act purposes, having a gross vehicle weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, and being a passenger automobile or light truck. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to any vehicle manufactured primarily for public streets with at least 4 wheels, excluding rail vehicles. It includes passenger automobiles and light trucks. The term 'motor vehicle' excludes rail vehicles and refers to any vehicle with at least 4 wheels manufactured primarily for public streets. It includes passenger automobiles and light trucks. The terms 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' are defined by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for the Clean Air Act administration. The average national unemployment rate for a calendar quarter is calculated as the average of monthly rates reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor. This amendment allows for a deduction in computing adjusted gross income under section 62 of the Code. The amendment allows for a deduction in computing adjusted gross income for qualified vehicle interest under section 62 of the Code, effective for vehicles acquired on or after January 1, 2008.
